abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Disaster
            Management Project for St. Lucia were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate;
            Bank performance was satisfactory and borrower performance
            was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: the
            passage of hurricane Tomas demonstrated that the emergency
            communication equipment was inadequate due to lack of
            maintenance. In future disaster vulnerability reduction
            operations, there is a need to finance full system solutions
            capable of transferring data and visuals in real time. The
            engagement of communities in identifying and addressing
            landslide risk reduction can bring good results. There is a
            need for significant capacity building on the use and
            interpretation of hazard and risk information. While
            maintenance plans have been developed for all the structures
            as part of the project, it is critical to ensure that the
            Government remains fully committed to allocating the
            necessary funding for periodic and scheduled maintenance.
            The Bank's ability to stay engaged with Saint Lucia in
            this agenda over a period of fifteen years has enabled the
            Bank and Saint Lucia to learn together and to gradually
            improve Saint Lucia's approach and capacity to manage
            disaster risk. Specific vulnerability reduction
            interventions reduce localized risk, but do not measurably
            reduce risk at a national level.
